(G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28; G.L. c. 209C, \.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; G.L. c. 215, § 6)

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28, G.L. c. 209C, \u.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as it is the court that entered the existing custody and parenting-time order and retains continuing jurisdiction to modify that order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the child’s best interests.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28;.proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody or parenting-time order upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Schwartz v. Schwartz, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 322, 325–26 (2011); Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146, 151–52 (2015).

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31;.proposition: In determining the best interests of a child in custody and parenting-time disputes, the Court’s “paramount concern” is the child’s welfare and happiness. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1996); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843–44 (2003).

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31;.proposition: Under these statutes and cases—G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and the line of cases including *Yannas*, *Mason*, *Murray*, *Rosenwasser*, *Schwartz*, *Custody of Vaughn*, and *Custody of Kali*—the Father’s relocation and the resulting hardships on the existing midweek overnight schedule constitute the sort of material change that authorizes and warrants judicial modification of parenting time.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 and 31; G.L.proposition: The requested modification is consistent with G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and Massachusetts case law (*Yannas*, *Mason*, *Murray*, *Rosenwasser*, *Schwartz*, *Custody of Vaughn*, *Custody of Kali*, *Hunter v. Rose*, and related authorities) and is in the best interests of the minor child.

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The need to re-evaluate parenting time where a parent moves a substantial distance from the child’s primary residence and school is widely recognized as a material change in circumstances under Massachusetts law, particularly where the existing schedule becomes impracticable or detrimental to the child’s best interests.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly quotes and relies on the ALI Principles §2.17, which state that “the relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances” when it significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise existing responsibilities, and that if relocation makes it impractical to maintain the same custodial proportions, the court should modify the parenting plan based on the child’s best interests. The court adopts this framework in the shared physical custody context, recognizing relocation that renders an existing schedule impractical as a substantial change triggering re-evaluation under a best‑interests standard.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
“The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:

‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances … only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgment of divorce],
…
‘(4) When a relocation constituting changed circumstances … renders it impractical to maintain the same proportion of custodial responsibility to each parent, the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests….’”

*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.proposition: The need to re-evaluate parenting time where a parent moves a substantial distance from the child’s primary residence and school is widely recognized as a material change in circumstances under Massachusetts law, particularly where the existing schedule becomes impracticable or detrimental to the child’s best interests.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal case focused on whether a primary custodial parent may relocate children out of the Commonwealth under the Yannas ‘real advantage/best interests’ framework. It does not involve or discuss a complaint to modify parenting time based on one parent’s already-completed move, nor does it characterize a long-distance move as a “material change in circumstances” requiring re‑evaluation of parenting time. The court analyzes removal standards under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not modification standards based on impracticability of an existing schedule; thus it does not support the precise proposition claimed.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.relevant_excerpt: “The removal from the Commonwealth of children of divorced parents is governed generally by G. L. c. 208, § 30… In determining whether cause for removal by the parent with primary physical custody has been shown under the statute, the judge must consider the custodial parent’s request under the familiar two-prong ‘real advantage’ test set forth in Yannas… and Hale… ‘[T]he first consideration is whether there is a good reason for the move, a “real advantage.”’ Second… the judge must consider whether the move is in the best interests of the children.”

*Schwartz v. Schwartz*, 79 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody or parenting-time order upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Schwartz v. Schwartz, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 322, 325–26 (2011); Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146, 151–52 (2015).
*Schwartz v. Schwartz*, 79 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Schwartz v. Schwartz, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 322 (2011), but rather a criminal case (Commonwealth v. Lawson or similar) involving a motion to suppress in a drug and motor vehicle prosecution. It does not concern Probate and Family Court, custody, parenting time, or modification standards, nor does it interpret G.L. c. 208, § 28. Accordingly, this opinion does not support the stated proposition about modification of custody or parenting-time orders.
*Schwartz v. Schwartz*, 79 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: The opinion discusses Fourth Amendment and art. 14 search-and-seizure issues related to a vehicle search and motion to suppress, but contains no language about custody, parenting time, or Probate and Family Court modification standards.

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595.proposition: In determining the best interests of a child in custody and parenting-time disputes, the Court’s “paramount concern” is the child’s welfare and happiness. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1996); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843–44 (2003).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the need to consider domestic violence explicitly in custody determinations and references G.L. c. 208, § 31, but in the provided excerpt it does not articulate the general best-interests standard as having the court’s ‘paramount concern’ be the child’s welfare and happiness. Its focus is on requiring explicit findings about domestic violence and its effects, not on stating or restating the overarching best-interests formulation. Without the specific ‘paramount concern’ language or an equivalent clear statement, this case as quoted does not directly support the proposition for which it is cited.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595.relevant_excerpt: The Legislature reached a similar conclusion in respect to shared legal or physical custody. General Laws c. 208, § 31, provides that “[i]f, despite the prior or current issuance of a restraining order against one parent pursuant to chapter two hundred and nine A, the court orders shared legal or physical custody . . . the court shall provide written findings to support such shared custody order.” A G. L. c. 209A order was outstanding in this case, and the judge made no explicit findings regarding the effect of shared custody on the child.

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.proposition: In determining the best interests of a child in custody and parenting-time disputes, the Court’s “paramount concern” is the child’s welfare and happiness. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1996); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843–44 (2003).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the ‘best interests of the child’ standard as the controlling test in custody matters and expressly characterizes the child’s best interests as the paramount concern. While the quoted language in the proposition paraphrases this as the child’s welfare and happiness, that phrasing is consistent with the court’s description of the standard and with its reliance on prior cases like Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas stating that the best interests of the children remain the paramount concern.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and it has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., … Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The Court must consider, among other factors, the child’s age, developmental needs, school and educational stability, the child’s emotional well-being, the child’s relationship with each parent, and the practical impact of any proposed parenting schedule. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 711–12 (1985); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183–84 (2006).
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition lists a broad, specific set of best-interest factors (age, developmental needs, educational stability, emotional well-being, relationships with each parent, and practical impact of schedules) as something the Court must consider, citing Yannas among others. Yannas does discuss the ‘best interests of the child’ in the removal context and mentions emotional, physical, and developmental needs, but it does not set out or require the full, detailed factor list described in the proposition (especially age, school/educational stability, or parenting schedules). Thus, it partially overlaps but does not support the proposition as framed.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u.proposition: The Court must consider, among other factors, the child’s age, developmental needs, school and educational stability, the child’s emotional well-being, the child’s relationship with each parent, and the practical impact of any proposed parenting schedule. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 711–12 (1985); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183–84 (2006).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u.support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman discusses the ‘best interests of the child’ standard generally and emphasizes that it is grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the child, but it does not set out or require consideration of the specific, itemized factors listed in the proposition (age, developmental needs, school stability, emotional well-being, relationships with each parent, and practical impact of schedule). The opinion instead focuses on removal in a joint-physical-custody context and, in applying the standard, mentions school quality, disruption, parental conflict, and parenting time, without purporting to define a mandatory, factor-based test. Thus, while consistent with a broad best-interests analysis, it does not provide direct authority for the specific multifactor proposition claimed.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u.relevant_excerpt: “‘The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985), citing Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 (1976). … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 566 (2000). Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.proposition: Substantial changes in the parties’ residences and the distance between the parents’ homes and the child’s school can constitute a material change warranting modification, particularly where the existing schedule imposes undue burdens on the child’s commuting time, school attendance, and extra-curricular participation.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal and child-support case, not a parenting-time or custody-modification case based on commuting or residential distance. Nowhere does the court discuss changes in the parents’ residences relative to the children’s school, commuting burdens, or extracurricular participation as a ‘material change’ warranting modification. The analysis centers on the Yannas ‘real advantage’ removal test and on child-support calculation, so it does not provide authority for the proposition described.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.relevant_excerpt: “Here, the judge did not err in finding that the proposed move would have clear and significant negative effects on the children and the father that were not outweighed by the benefits that would inure to the mother. That decision is supported by the record and the judge’s copious findings of fact; we accordingly discern no error.” (Context: this is in the course of applying the Yannas removal test, not addressing material change based on commuting or residential distance.)

*Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser*, 89 Mass. A.proposition: Substantial changes in the parties’ residences and the distance between the parents’ homes and the child’s school can constitute a material change warranting modification, particularly where the existing schedule imposes undue burdens on the child’s commuting time, school attendance, and extra-curricular participation.
*Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser*, 89 Mass. A.case_name: West Beit Olam Cemetery Corp. v. Board of Assessors
*Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser*, 89 Mass. A.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns property tax exemption for cemetery land and buildings under G.L. c. 59, § 5, cl. Twelfth, not family law or modification of parenting schedules. It does not discuss parental residences, distance to a child’s school, commuting burdens, or any custody/visitation modification standards. Therefore it provides no authority for the claimed proposition about material change in circumstances in the parenting context.
*Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser*, 89 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: This is an appeal from a decision of the Appellate Tax Board (board) by West Beit Olam Cemetery Corporation (West Beit Olam), a nonprofit corporation... In particular, we conclude that the board properly denied a tax exemption for the large part of lot 1A and a building located on it that were contractually restricted to residential use for seven years, including the tax year in question.

*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at.raw_text: *Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at 153–55
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that long commutes which interfere with a child’s sleep, schooling, or stability may be contrary to the child’s best interests and may justify revising parenting time to reduce midweek travel. See *Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at 153–55; *Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser*, 89 Mass. App. Ct. at 681–83.

*Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser*, 89 Mass. A.raw_text: *Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser*, 89 Mass. App. Ct. at 681–83
*Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser*, 89 Mass. A.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that long commutes which interfere with a child’s sleep, schooling, or stability may be contrary to the child’s best interests and may justify revising parenting time to reduce midweek travel. See *Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at 153–55; *Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser*, 89 Mass. App. Ct. at 681–83.

*Care & Protection of Georgette*, 439 Ma.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 31 and related case law, the Court has broad equitable powers to adjust parenting time and allocation of custodial rights to protect the child’s best interests and to address changes in circumstances. See *Care & Protection of Georgette*, 439 Mass. 28, 38 (2003); *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 493–94 (2012).
*Care & Protection of Georgette*, 439 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion in Care & Protection of Georgette concerns ineffective assistance/conflict of interest of children’s counsel and standards for counsel’s role in care and protection/termination proceedings. It does not interpret G.L. c. 208, § 31, does not involve divorce or allocation of custodial rights between parents, and does not discuss the court’s equitable power to modify parenting time based on changed circumstances. Using this case as authority for broad equitable powers under § 31 misattributes a proposition that the decision neither addresses nor implies.
*Care & Protection of Georgette*, 439 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “There is no question that the children are entitled to counsel, that their autonomy and rights to be heard on issues affecting their interest should be respected, and that their positions, based on mature expression, are entitled to weight in custody proceedings (although not determinative). See Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595, 602 (1981); Adoption of Arthur, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 914, 915 (1993). Nonetheless, we have noted that, ‘[e]ven where it is undisputed that a child and her attorney disagree, the law is unclear….’”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 493\u20.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 31 and related case law, the Court has broad equitable powers to adjust parenting time and allocation of custodial rights to protect the child’s best interests and to address changes in circumstances. See *Care & Protection of Georgette*, 439 Mass. 28, 38 (2003); *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 493–94 (2012).
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 493\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly applies G.L. c. 208, § 31 and related best‑interests case law in reviewing and affirming the Probate and Family Court judge’s custody and parenting-time determinations. It reiterates that custody determinations rest within the judge’s discretion, require weighing all relevant factors under § 31, and endorses the judge’s ability to structure custody and visitation (including a detailed parenting schedule and an adjustment mechanism if Rose returns to Massachusetts) to protect the child’s best interests in light of changing circumstances such as relocation and parental conduct.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 493\u20.relevant_excerpt: “‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’…. The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge … [whose] findings … ‘must stand unless they are plainly wrong.’ … However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31.’ … [T]he judge’s custody order gave Rose frequent contact with Jill… [and] stated that, should Rose decide to move back to Massachusetts, the parties must work in good faith to adjust their parenting plan to meet Jill’s best interests.”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. at 595\u2.proposition: The Court may also consider the child’s anxiety, stress, and emotional reaction to a parenting schedule as part of the best-interest analysis, especially when tied to objectively burdensome logistics. See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. at 595–97; *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 843–44; *Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at 153–55.

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 843\u201.proposition: The Court may also consider the child’s anxiety, stress, and emotional reaction to a parenting schedule as part of the best-interest analysis, especially when tied to objectively burdensome logistics. See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. at 595–97; *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 843–44; *Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at 153–55.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: While meaningful contact with both parents is important and Mother fully supports an ongoing relationship between Father and Sophia, such contact must be structured in a manner that is realistically compatible with the geographic distance between the parties and with the child’s age, schooling, and developmental needs. See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. at 711–12; *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. at 183–84.

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. at 183\u20.proposition: While meaningful contact with both parents is important and Mother fully supports an ongoing relationship between Father and Sophia, such contact must be structured in a manner that is realistically compatible with the geographic distance between the parties and with the child’s age, schooling, and developmental needs. See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. at 711–12; *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. at 183–84.
